Announcing regex-lite: A Lightweight Regex Engine for Searching Strings

2023/07/05
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.
<p>The regex-lite crate provides a lightweight regex engine for searching strings. It offers a syntax that is nearly identical to the popular regex crate. However, regex-lite prioritizes smaller binary sizes and shorter Rust compile times over performance and functionality. As a result, regex searches in this crate may be slower compared to the regex crate. Additionally, regex-lite has limited Unicode support, only matching codepoint by codepoint.</p> <p>To use regex-lite, simply add it as a dependency in your project&apos;s Cargo.toml file. Here&apos;s an example of how to use regex-lite in a Rust project:</p> <ol> <li>Create a new Rust project:</li> </ol> <pre><code>$ cargo new my_project $ cd my_project </code></pre> <ol start="2"> <li>Add regex-lite as a dependency:</li> </ol> <pre><code># Cargo.toml [dependencies] regex-lite = &quot;0.1&quot; </code></pre> <ol start="3"> <li>Edit src/main.rs with the following code:</li> </ol> <pre><code class="language-rust">use regex_lite::Regex; fn main() { let haystack = &quot;Hello, world!&quot;; let pattern = r&quot;world&quot;; let re = Regex::new(pattern).unwrap(); if let Some(captures) = re.captures(haystack) { let match_str = captures.get(0).unwrap().as_str(); println!(&quot;Found match: {}&quot;, match_str); } else { println!(&quot;No match found&quot;); } } </code></pre> <ol start="4"> <li>Run the program:</li> </ol> <pre><code>$ cargo run </code></pre> <p>This example demonstrates a basic regex search using regex-lite. For more examples and detailed API documentation, refer to the official documentation.</p>
